 REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN TREASURY MODERNIZATION PROJECT Technical Annex 1. INTRODUCTION 1. In its four years of independence, Kazakstan has made substantial progress toward creating a market economy and achieving macroeconomic stability. Maintenance of macroeconomic stability requires, among other things, policies that will hold the fiscal deficit to manageable levels. Restraining the fiscal deficit will depend upon sound strategy and management on both the revenue and expenditure sides of the budget. 2. To boost revenues, a taxation policy has been drafted and a new streamlined tax code has been designed and should be adopted by Parliament in 1995. An International Monetary Fund (IMF) Tax Administration Advisor has been providing technical assistance in the development of software for the tax administration system. This will be accompanied by measures to strengthen the Tax Inspection Service, supported by United States Agency for International Development (USAID)- financed technical assistance. 3. Much work, however, remains to be done on government expenditure management and control. Establishing a treasury system in the Treasury Department (TD) within the Ministry of Finance (MOF) has been given high priority by the government and is a critical requirement for sound management of public finances. Although the proposed treasury system would have linkages with other government financial operations, specifically revenue operations, the government has decided to address tax administration separately. Substantial work has already been undertaken in the area of tax reform with funding from other donors. The World Bank's financing of the proposed treasury modernization project to enhance government expenditure management and control is appropriate and timely. 4. A TD was formally established in the MOF by Presidential decree on January 27, 1994 with the principal aim of managing the government expenditures, assets and liabilities. The Deputy Minister of Finance was appointed as the Director of the TD. The TD has a current staff of 28 ( which will be 56 when fully established) and plans to administer a comprehensive and reliable financial information system for the day-to-day management of government expenditures. To achieve this, the TD has been assigned a number of responsibilities, including regular analysis, reporting on the execution of the budget; cash and debt management; accounting for government financial operations; and treasury system computerization. The management of both domestic and external debt will be an integral function of the TD; a branch of the Cash Management Division of the TD will have the responsibility of external debt management and all the existing external management functions will be incorporated in this branch unit. The 1995 program of the TD included establishing regional treasury units which will take over budget execution and primary accounting responsibilities from the National Bank of Kazakstan (NBK), and introduction of the required reforms to centralize fiscal monitoring and control functions in the MOF. 5. Organizational development of the TD is only the first step in establishing an efficient treasury system. Basic banking and accounting arrangements will have to be redesigned to support
 -2 - treasury functions and new procedures, developed to support the new revenue and expenditure classification and to ensure that the TD plays an effective role in controlling government expenditures. The government has decided to establish a computerized treasury system in a planned and phased program to facilitate management of government expenditures and has requested World Bank 's financing for its implementation. II. OVERVIEW OF A TREASURY SYSTEM FOR KAZAKSTAN Background 6. Government treasury management is defined as a set of rules, practices, and procedures with the aim of distributing funds, accounting for their use, producing periodic financial reports and making cash resources of the government more productive and the borrowing of funds less expensive. The advantages of good treasury management, principles of effective cash management and institutional and organizational aspects of treasury systems are discussed in Annex 1. 7. The current public expenditure management processes in Kazakstan largely reflect the centrally-planned economic system inherited from the time of the former Soviet Union (FSU). The role of the fiscal machinery in that system was in the elaboration and implementation of successive National Economic Plans. In that context, the preparation of the annual budget was the comrnmon responsibility of the central planning authority (initially GOSPLAN, subsequently the State Economic Committee). The demise of the planning system in Kazakstan caused a breakdown in budget programming and control mechanisms. The collapse of the unifying authority of the Party has left local administrations with a degree of financial autonomy incommensurate with the accountability to which they are subject. The role of the MOF in budget execution process became marginal, spending units committed expenditures at their discretion, and the NBK performed payment/public accounting/cash management functions. The MOF only controlled the release of funds to spending units' accounts, and even that only at the central level. In this situation the MOF was mainly responsible for reconciling information received from the NBK, ministries, regions and districts and producing the statement of monthly outcome for the republican budget. Reports from regions (incorporating details from districts) were forwarded to the MOF every month for consolidation into the outcome of local budgets. The republican and local figures were then combined to produce a monthly statement for the State. At all these stages, information was compiled manually with very little recourse to automation. Little information was generated internally by the MOF, which operated primarily as a consolidating agency with very limited control over budget execution. 8. Cash management was also largely nonexistent. Very little capacity existed to monitor daily cash flows in government accounts, cash resources were not used efficiently and expenditure estimates were based on norms, not realistically related to likely revenues. Reliable and comprehensive accounting information was not available on a timely basis. Responsibilities for fiscal matters appear to be diffused amnong a number of different entities within the government. Inappropriate budget classifications did not allow meaningful assessment of fiscal and economic data, which diminished budgetary control. 9. Successive IMF technical assistance missions have, first, identified the institutional and conceptual weaknesses in the public expenditure management system, and, second, proposed a series of reforms which the government has accepted and, with Fund and other external assistance, is
 nearing completion of implementing many critical components. The major weaknesses could be sunmarized as follows: diffusion of responsibilities for fiscal matters among a number of different entities within the government in addition to the MOF; inappropriate budget classifications, based on productive and nonproductive categories which did not allow meaningful budget monitoring; an inappropriate legal framework for budget preparation, approval, implementation and reporting; lack of a macroeconomic framework necessary for formulation of the budget and elaboration of revenue and expenditure projections; lack of reliable and comprehensive accounting information available on a timely basis; and lack of essential cash and debt management capabilities; and the appropriate legal framework for borrowing, recording and for controlling loan arrangements and government guarantees. Reforms to Date 10. Overcoming the problems in the then existing fiscal system required adoption of a number of reforms. Measures for institutional strengthening, adoption of the required legal and regulatory framework, subjecting central and local administrations to the financial authority of the MOF, introducing a new budget law capable of proper budget programming and control, introducing public debt laws and a computerized debt management system, are among the reforms which are now largely implemented. These reforms, which accompanied the establishment of a Treasury system, can be sunmmarized as follows: the republican budget has been reclassified to conform with Government Finance Statistics (GFS) methodology and to be more suitable for economic analysis. The classification system also addresses organization arrangements and is therefore suitable for budget preparation, parliamentary appropriation and for computerized budget execution. The new classification has been adopted by the government and has been in use in Ministries and agencies since April 1, 1996; a new budget system law has been drafted with assistance from a U.S. Treasury Budget Advisor and substantial input from the IMF Treasury Advisor. It is in the final stages of government consideration; and internal debt management operations have been consolidated within the recently formed Treasury Department (TD)--see below--and, with assistance from USAID, the UNCTAD Debt Management and Financial Analysis System (DMFAS) is being installed for control and reporting purposes;
 - 4 - funds are released periodically by the TD, based on cash flow forecasts and expenditure plans of Ministries. Funds are further distributed by Ministries to spending units. 11. The development of comprehensive accounting information and a systematic approach to budget implementation and cash management is best carried out through an integrated computerized treasury system operated through a Treasury Department. With IMF assistance, the Government has developed an integrated strategy, covering three main elements to introduce the computerized treasury system. These elements are: (i) centralizing financial operations in a single bank account--a Treasury Single Account (TSA); (ii) establishing a Treasury Ledger System (TLS); and (iii) computerizing the TLS for the processing of payments and receipts. To date the single account has been established in the National Bank of Kazakstan. A TD was formally established in the MOF by a Presidential decree on January 27, 1994 with the principal aim of managing the government expenditures, assets and liabilities. The Deputy Minister of Finance was appointed as the Director of the TD. The TD has been assigned a number of responsibilities, including regular analysis, reporting and execution of the budget; cash and debt management; accounting for government financial operations; and treasury system computerization. As stated earlier, the management of domestic debt is now an integral function of the TD. Organizationally the TD has the following six major divisions: (a) the Financial Accounting and Analysis Division is responsible for drawing up monthly, quarterly, and annual reports on revenues and expenditures of the Republican Budget. (b) the Republican Budget Execution Division is responsible for assigning revenues and expenditure under the Republican Budget, and for determining expenditure requirements of ministries and spending units. (c) the Monetary Credit Policy Division. (d) the Cash and State Debts Division is responsible for cash management, internal and external debt management, control of government guarantees, issue of securities and interaction with the NBK. (e) the Informatics Division, and (f) the Supervision of the Budget Cash Execution Division which is responsible for supervision of the recently taken over NBK cash settlement centers. 12. Other divisions are responsible for development of methodological procedures and financial statistics and analysis. 13. The proposed project, to fully design and computerize the treasury system, is the logical conclusion and important final step in implementing the series of wide ranging Public Expenditure Management (PEM) reforms undertaken by the government.
 Impementation of Computerized Treasury System 14. The MOF is in the process of implementing many of the recommendations of the IMF related to treasury system implementation. The detailed definition and computerization of the treasury system, the subject of this loan, is a key element in the overall reform process, and attracts a high priority from the government perspective because of the need to ensure sound management of public finances. 15. As mentioned above, with IMF assistance, the government has developed an integrated strategy, covering three elements, to introduce the computerized treasury system. These elements are: (i) centralizing financial operations in a single bank account - a Treasury Single Account (TSA); (ii) establishing a Treasury Ledger System (TLS); and (iii) designing and operating the computerization of the TLS and the processing of payments and receipts. The strategy calls for phased introduction of the system in three main stages: (i) project preparation (1994-96); (ii) implementation of a pilot automation system covering a group of ministries and selected Regional Treasury Units (RTU) (1996-97); and (iii) replication of the pilot system across all ministries, RTUs and District Treasury Units (DTU) (1998-1999). Each stage would start upon substantial completion of the preceding stage, determined by MOF and World Bank acceptance of the deliverables listed for that stage. A T reasury Advisor has been appointed by the IMF to work closely with TD staff and the selected consulting firm, financed under the PPF, to assist the TD in design and preparation of the project. Detailed description of the functional design of the treasury system the Government of Kazakstan plans to implement, and the hardware and software strategy for implementing the treasury system is included in Annex 1. III. THE PROJECT Project Objective 16. The project's overall aim is to support the new TD in establishing a treasury system: (i) that provides comprehensive, reliable and timely financial management information; and (ii) helps manage government expenditure effectively. To achieve this aim, the project sets three specific objectives: (i) prepare a detailed functional design for the treasury system and develop related procedures; (ii) provide and install the computer resources to implement the treasury system; and (iii) ensure that local staff can operate and maintain the system effectively. Project Description 17. The project consists of the following components: (a) Design of the Computerized Treasury System. This component consists of: (i) preparing a detailed functional design for the treasury system and developing related procedures and manuals; (ii) examining available software alternatives; (iii) developing hardware and software specifications for the technology platform needed to establish the system and assist in their procurement; and (iv) formulating a programn to train the TD and other related staff and upgrading the Government's in-house technical capacity to operate and maintain the system. A consultant firm was selected by the Government to
 - 6 - carry out this task. A Project Preparation Facility in the amount of US$1 million was approved on July 14, 1994 to finance this work; (b) Pilot System Computerization. Based on the work carried out under component (a), application software would be designed and procured to test and implement the full functionality of the Treasury System at a few designated sites. Computer hardware system and software would be procured to implement the pilot at the sites. At this stage, user manuals, training materials and technical documentation will be finalized and the local staff will be trained to operate and maintain the system. (c) Full Implementation of the Computerized System. Based on the finalized system under component (b), computer hardware and standard software will be procured and installed for the rest of the treasury system. A Government wide training program will be implemented simultaneously for operating and maintaining the system. Status of Preparation 18. Detailed Functional Design. System designs and functional specification for payroll, commitment accounting, revenue accounting, cash management, fixed asset control, general ledger and chart of accounts (comprising a majority of the functions) have been completed by the consultants and approved by the Government 19. Software Alternatives. Investigation of available off the shelf software packages that meet the functional requirements of the treasury system has been started. While conducting a search for software packages the consultants will ensure that: (a) the software packages provide the required functionality; (b) it is possible to obtain and install upgrades and/or changes to the packages in Kazakstan as they become available; (c) the vendor for the package provides customization assistance as may be required or alternatively the package source code is available for making changes as may be required; (d) the costs associated with any customization are identified clearly in the total cost; (e) the package runs on a range of hardware and operating software which is compliant with the hardware and software strategy proposed for the treasury system; (f) adequate documentation is available to enable package installation and use, and (g) licensing arrangements clearly specify the liability for use of the package at multiple sites in Kazakstan. 20. In case it is not found feasible to purchase an off the shelf package to satisfy the requirements of the treasury system, the consultants will develop a plan for the design and development of the application systems. In this case, the consultants will also extend the functional analysis performed above and develop the systems and program specifications for the various modules of the treasury and related systems. These would then be used as the basis for the contracting (or in-house development) of the application software. 21. Development of hardware and software specifications and acquisition of hardware and software. Hardware and software specifications are being completed by the consultants and progress was reviewed with the Government during the appraisal. The bidding document for the procurement of hardware and software for the pilot phase implementation is also under preparation.
 22. Development/upgrading the MOF data processing organization. The government will require the development/upgrading of its in-house data processing facilities to maintain and operate the treasury and associated systems developed as part of this project. The MOF computer department has a staff of competent analysts and programmers. A team of about 8-10 staff from this center will be designated by the government to work along with the consultants. This staff will need to be involved with all tasks associated with systems design, software development, installation and operation. In case one or more software packages are selected to satisfy the requirements of the treasury system, the staff will need to be trained in their use and maintenance. In case in-house development is required, staff will be associated with the in-house development of the system or the management of the contractors who have been selected to carry out the development. 23. The consultants will analyze the existing MOF's EDP resources and develop a plan to upgrade the data processing organization. This would include assisting the TD in developing a training program for its staff including specialized training in the use of the various tools such as operating systems and DBMSs application development facilities, and more general training in EDP project management, maintenance and provision of end user support and training for a country wide system treasury system. Implementation Strategy 24. Under project preparation, significant progress has been made to prepare for project implementation. Detailed function for the treasury system has been completed by consultants and approved by the TD. Bidding documents for procurement of pilot hardware and software are being completed and progress was reviewed during appraisal. Broad outline of a training program has been drawn-up and was reviewed with the Government during appraisal. Search for available software alternatives has also begun. By loan effectiveness, most of the preparatory work should be completed. The first phase of implementation would focus mainly on finalizing the training plan and procedures and manuals for the new system. 25. The implementation of the project is divided into three phases: completion of the functional design of the system to be tested (as described in paragraph 18); a pilot phase to procure and test the system; followed by implementation of the full system. Accordingly, the hardware and standard software packages to be purchased under the project will be divided into two phases. The pilot phase would implement the application systems and installation of new hardware at the central Treasury, two of the central spending units (sector ministries), two oblasts and some associated rayons to thoroughly test the features and functionality of the system, the integration between the first and second level packages, and work out the data migration strategy. Hardware procurement at this stage will be limited to the pilot project requirement. The bid documents for the pilot phase has been prepared and submitted to the Bank for review prior to Board presentation. 26. Based on the modifications made during the pilot phase, hardware will be procured for the full implementation phase. Simultaneously, training of local staff would be conducted to carry out the replication and subsequent operation and maintenance of the system. Prior to the commencement of the full implementation phase, a Mid-Term Review will be carried out with the Government to precisely define the hardware and standard software packages to be procured, their costs, and the implementation schedule for replicating the system country-wide. Prior to the Mid- Term Review, the draft bid documents for the full implementation phase will be prepared and submitted to the Bank for review.

Treasury system training. The training strategy aims to develop a cadre of professionals able to develop and operate the treasury system, and to strengthen commitment to the reform process.
 - 9 - By matching the investment in systems with a parallel investment in people, the full benefits of the system can be achieved. Given the extensive training needs identified, the chosen modality is a cascade approach, the essential aim being to train limited numbers of key people who will then train much larger numbers of subordinates. Two main groups of training skills are needed: (i) accounting, financial management and auditing; (ii) informnation technology and software applications. 30. The following target groups have been identified: system developers and administrators, applications managers, personnel responsible for transaction processing, end-users, personnel of the budget bank, senior managers, accountants and government auditors. 31. For successful implementation of the project, a separate unit is required for treasury training, appropriately linked with the department for personnel issues and educational institutions of the Ministry of Finance. The unit, with technical assistance from the project, would have the general responsibility for creating and implementing an annual training program for the Treasury Department, setting out the courses to be designed and delivered, their objectives and duration, numbers to be trained, the locations for training and the necessary inputs from various sources. The plan would be approved by the Deputy Minister of Finance annually. 32. The main training modules would be: elements of govermnent accounting, financial management, internal control and internal audit; overview of the treasury system (appreciation course); financial procedures; transactions processing for budget execution; information technology; application systems; site management procedures; and courses for end-users. The above would be designed as permanent courses to run regularly after completion of the project. Training would be provided principally by the training unit of the Treasury Department with help from other divisions, and from selected commercial firms and training institutions. 33. In association with the September 1996 project launch (see above), the first formal training seminar will be held. During implementation, further workshops will be organized for managers, senior financial staff, accountants and trainers in line ministries, oblasts, audit bodies and training institutions. The training strategy and program and the Project launch are further described in Annex 2.

Total project costs are estimated to amount to US$21.7 million, of which foreign exchange costs are calculated at US$19.3 million, or 89% of the total. Local costs have been estimated on the basis of current and foreseeable salary and accommodation needs. Costs for various components have been estimated in November 1995 using the experience of other World Bank projects in the region, similar activities in neighboring countries and detailed input from various counterparts. The estimates include physical contingency amounting to US$0.92 million, which is comprised of: (i) 5 percent of the cost of computer hardware and related equipment procurement; (ii) 15 percent of the cost of application software; and, (iii) 15 % of the cost of training. All equipment, installation, training and foreign consultant costs have been estimated net of taxes and duties. The consultants which have been engaged by the Government to assist in the project preparation are also expected to continue to assist during the implementation phase (per contract). US$1 million of the $1.50 million is being financed under the PPF and the remaining contract amount will be financed by the project loan. 35. The main financial contribution of the Government, equivalent to 27 percent of total project cost, would be the incremental staffing cost for the new computerized treasury system; associated hardware and software maintenance costs for the outer years of the project (years four and five); other recurrent expenditure costs associated with operating the new treasury system, including computer supplies and communication charges; for the period covering project implementation (July 1996 to December 2000). The Government financial contribution totals US$5.9 million. The Bank would thus finance 82 percent of foreign exchange costs and 73 percent of total project costs. The Project Cost and Financing Plan is summarized in Schedule A. 36. Institutional Arrangements for Project Coordination and Implementation. doc.abstracts: The Treasury Modernization Project's overall aim is to support the new Treasury Department in establishing a treasury system: a) that provides comprehensive, reliable and timely financial management information; and b) that helps manage government expenditure effectively. To achieve this aim, the project sets three specific objectives: a) prepare a detailed functional design for the treasury system and develop related procedures; b) provide and install the computer resources to implement the treasury system; and c) ensure that local staff can operate and maintain the system effectively. The project consists of the following components: a) design of the computerized treasury system; b) pilot system computerization; and c) full implementation of the computerized system.
